items.synopsis: In the 1967 referendum on Indigenous rights, the NSW electorate of Cowper recorded one of the highest "no" votes. Now, Gumbaynggirr elders are reflecting on past lessons as they prepare for the second Indigenous referendum in their lifetime.

title.children: 'Feels like hatred': Meet the town that voted 'no' in the last Indigenous referendum

image.altText: A woman cries in front of a car.

items.synopsis: The woman who hosted the lunch that police believe resulted in three people dying from mushroom poisoning has spoken of her anguish at the deaths and denied doing anything wrong.

title.children: 'I didn't do anything, I loved them': Cook of mushroom meal police suspect killed three people protests innocence

image.altText: A group of soccer players wearing yellow and green hug each other while celebrating a win

items.synopsis: Having grappled with their heavyweight status, the Matildas defeated Denmark in the way only a serious World Cup contender should.

title.children: Are the Matildas coming of age after mature World Cup win over Denmark?

image.altText: Australian female soccer players jump high in celebration in front of a crowd of fans

items.synopsis: When will the Sam Kerr-captained side play again, and who will they be clashing with in the quarterfinals of the FIFA Women's World Cup?

title.children: The Matildas have won their World Cup match against Denmark. What happens next?

image.altText: Person sleeping face down.

items.synopsis: Non-Indigenous Australians are 18 per cent more likely to die due to extreme heat compared to Indigenous Australians, a study has found. The remedy is common sense, according to a Warumungu elder.

title.children: How taking a nap instead of cranking the aircon could help us survive 'killer' heat

image.altText: Portraits of Mark Zuckerberg and Elon Musk side by side

items.synopsis: SpaceX and Tesla CEO Elon Musk is yet to commit to a date for the physical fight while his opponent, Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg declares himself "ready".

title.children: Zuckerberg not 'holding my breath' over fight as Musk flags upcoming surgery

image.altText: A composite image of Christopher Pyne and Joe Hockey

items.synopsis: In Australia there has long been disquiet about the revolving door between high political office and big business. Look at the defence industry, for example, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: A new generation of former MPs has turned to big business

items.synopsis: All five Renewable Energy Zones are still in the planning phase and no additional transmission infrastructure to support the new projects has been built.

title.children: Renewable Energy Zones are touted to replace NSW's coal power. Will they be ready in time?

image.altText: An aerial photo of eight horses and foals jumping across a small creek in a national park.

items.synopsis: For some the brumby is a national icon that encapsulates what Australia is. For others it's a pest that's out of control.

title.children: Aerial shooting of brumbies to reduce numbers is back on the agenda. How did we get here?

image.altText: The icon for the video sharing TikTok app is seen on a smartphone.

items.synopsis: TikTok is starting a massive recruitment drive for tech workers in Sydney in a move one expert says is linked to concerns over its links with China.

title.children: TikTok respond to data security concerns with massive recruitment drive

image.altText: Hayley Raso smiles and is hugged by her teammates

items.synopsis: The Matildas beat Denmark 2-0 to reach FIFA Women's World Cup quarterfinals. Earlier, England edges past Nigeria 4-2 on penalties in Brisbane.

title.children: 'We didn't get rattled': Matildas strike back after Danish assault to reach World Cup quarters

image.altText: Men in prisoner greens move scaffolding in front of home under construction.

items.synopsis: Correctional Services NSW has agreed to increase the number of inmate-built modular homes for the Aboriginal Housing Office, with a real need for five-bedroom homes and a workforce eager to build skills.

title.children: Inmates eager to ramp up home building for Indigenous communities

image.altText: People silhouetted against a white and blue KPMG logo.

items.synopsis: Newly compiled data reveals Defence has spent nearly $4 billion on large consulting firms over the past decade, more than all other Australian government departments combined.

title.children: 'Something's rotten': New analysis reveals $4 billion Defence department spend on consultancy firms

image.altText: a red Tesla Model 3 sedan is charged at a Tesla dealership with the Tesla logo shown on the dealership building in the back

items.synopsis: Tesla's chief financial officer, Zachary Kirkhorn, leaves the electric car-maker, and the ASX is higher after a rise on Wall Street ahead of the inflation report.  Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Elon Musk successor steps down from Tesla, ASX gains after Wall Street rally ahead of inflation report

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The National Australia Bank says business confidence has lifted slightly to be back in positive territory in July. However it is still low at 2 index points. Business conditions eased 1 point to 10 index points. Trading conditions, employment and profitability were all steady according to NAB chief economist Alan Oster. “Business conditions continued to show resilience in July and have been broadly steady in the past couple of months at above-average levels," he says. “Business confidence also picked up in July to be back in positive territory as well, although confidence remains low.” However, forward orders remain in negative territory, dragged down by the retail sector, and costs continue to rise for companies including for electricity and wages. “Labour cost growth rose sharply in July, likely reflecting wage rises taking effect on July 1 including minimum and award wage changes,” said Mr Oster. “Labour cost growth was strongest in recreation & personal services, transport & utilities, and retail, which aligns with where we would expect minimum and award wage workers to be most common.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Business confidence picks up even though costs rise

children.content: The National Australia Bank says business confidence has lifted slightly to be back in positive territory
in July.
However it is still low at 2 index points.
Business conditions eased 1 point to 10 index points.

props.alt: Table and graph showing business conditions and confidence

children.content: NAB business survey
(NAB)
Trading conditions, employment and profitability were all steady according to
NAB chief economist Alan Oster.
“Business conditions continued to show resilience in July and have been broadly steady in the past couple of months at above-average levels," he says.
“Business confidence also picked up in July to be back in positive territory as well, although confidence remains low.”
However, forward orders remain in negative territory, dragged down by the retail sector, and costs continue to rise for companies including for electricity and wages.
“Labour cost growth rose sharply in July, likely reflecting wage rises taking effect on July 1 including minimum and award wage changes,” said Mr Oster.
“Labour cost growth was strongest in recreation
personal services, transport
utilities, and retail, which aligns with where we would expect minimum and award wage workers to be most common.”

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Consumer confidence remains deeply in pessimistic territory amid high interest rates, high inflation and the slowing economy. Westpac and the Melbourne Institute says consumer sentiment dropped 0.4 per cent to 81 in August. A figure below 100 shows there are more pessimists than optimists. Westpac senior economist Matthew Hassan says the Reserve Bank interest rate pauses last month and this month have done little to lift confidence, probably because the RBA has warned that more rate rises may be needed. "The August survey detail pointed to little or no impact from the RBA’s decision to pause. " "Responses showed no improvement over the course of survey week, sentiment instead declining 4.9 per cent between those surveyed prior to the RBA decision and those surveyed after." "The sub-group detail also continued to show a disappointing reaction from the mortgage belt – sentiment amongst consumers with a mortgage down 7.2 per cent in the August month and, 0.8 per cent below its June level despite the two-month pause." "Most consumers are still bracing for further rate rises with over two-thirds of those surveyed after the RBA decision expecting rates to move higher over the year ahead, nearly half of this group expecting a rise of over 1 percentage point." He says consumers are worried about inflation, including recent fuel and energy price rises, with pressure on family finances and concerns about rates and the economic outlook.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consumer confidence falls

children.content: Consumer confidence remains deeply in pessimistic territory amid high interest rates, high inflation and the slowing economy.
Westpac and the Melbourne Institute says consumer sentiment dropped 0.4 per cent to 81 in August.
A figure below 100 shows there are more pessimists than optimists.
Westpac senior economist Matthew Hassan
says the Reserve Bank interest rate pauses last month and this month have done little to lift confidence, probably because the RBA has warned that more rate rises may be needed.
"The August survey detail pointed to little or no impact from the RBA’s decision to pause. "
"Responses showed no improvement over the course of survey week, sentiment instead declining 4.9 per cent between those surveyed prior to the RBA decision and those surveyed after."

"The sub-group detail also continued to show a disappointing reaction from the mortgage belt – sentiment amongst consumers with a mortgage down 7.2 per cent in the August month and, 0.8 per cent below its June level despite the two-month pause."

"Most consumers are still bracing for further rate rises with over two-thirds of those surveyed after the RBA decision expecting rates to move higher over the year ahead, nearly half of this group expecting a rise of over 1 percentage point."
He says consumers are worried about inflation, including recent fuel and energy price rises, with pressure on family finances and concerns about rates and the economic outlook.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has opened higher after a rebound on Wall Street. The ASX 200 index has put on 0.3 per cent. Miners and banks have edged up, but most sectors are in the red so far including healthcare stocks. Spot gold fell on concerns of further interest rate rises by the Federal Reserve and iron ore prices dropped amid further cuts in steel production by China. Oil prices were also caught up in the selling after last week's highs on reduced supply. ASX 200 best and worst performers: James Hardie: +14.6% after seeing underlying profit grow over the first quarter. Lake Resources: +5.7% Domain: +2.6% Coronado Global Resources: -11.7% after net profit slumped by two-thirds for the half year to $199 million. Charter Hall: -3.5% Sayona Mining: -3.3%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens higher

children.content: The Australian share market has opened higher after a rebound on Wall Street.
The ASX 200 index has put on 0.3 per cent.
Miners and banks have edged up, but most sectors are in the red so far including healthcare stocks.
Spot gold fell on concerns of further interest rate rises by the Federal Reserve and iron ore prices dropped amid further cuts in steel production by China.
Oil prices were also caught up in the selling after last week's highs on reduced supply.
ASX 200 best and worst performers:
James Hardie: +14.6% after seeing underlying profit grow over the first quarter.
Lake Resources: +5.7%
Domain: +2.6%
Coronado Global Resources: -11.7% after net profit slumped by two-thirds for the half year to $199 million.
Charter Hall: -3.5%
Sayona Mining: -3.3%

image.altText: An Australian para-cyclist smiles and waves as she holds her gold medal in her hand.

items.synopsis: Emily Petricola doubles Australia's gold medal tally at the cycling worlds but Logan Martin has to settle for silver in the BMX freestyle.

title.children: Para-cyclist Emily Petricola claims second Aussie gold at world cycling titles

image.altText: man walking away from camera in snow

items.synopsis: Trail runners and police urge people to "be prepared for the unexpected" after a runner was lost for several hours in the Victorian Alps.

title.children: Wrong turn in the snow, 25km off course, but chance encounter saves runner's life

image.altText: A man and three women walk along a dirt track in outback Australia.

items.synopsis: A date for the Voice to Parliament referendum is yet to be announced because "there are still so many" Australians that need to be reached, Labor senator Malarndirri McCarthy tells Q+A during a special broadcast from Garma Festival.

title.children: 'The earlier the better, prime minister': Voice referendum date yet to be set amid promise of no delays

image.altText: Man in black suit and blue shirt wearing glasses

items.synopsis: The former Minneapolis police officer is unrepentant for his role in the killing, claiming during his sentencing hearing that his "conscience is clear".

title.children: Final police officer sentenced over George Floyd murder

image.altText: Men arrested, children removed in global child sexual abuse investigation

items.synopsis: The Australian Federal Police reveals details of the joint FBI operation targeting child abuse material on the dark web.

title.children: Murder of two FBI agents leads to Australian sex abuse operation, removal of children

image.altText: America Ferrera in a white dress standing in front of a pink Barbie convertible with Barbie written behind her

items.synopsis: America Ferrera has gone viral in recent weeks for her feminist monologue in Barbie, which is a turning point in the film.

title.children: Loved America Ferrera's Barbie monologue? She's been building up to it her whole career

image.altText: A pile of Australian dollar coins on top of several bank notes

items.synopsis: Despite years of trade surpluses and a budget surplus to boot, the Australian dollar is on the slide once more — and it's all thanks to commodities and interest rates, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: The Australian dollar is on the slide, and no-one knows just how low it will go

image.altText: Lee Hsien Loong speaks during a press conference.

items.synopsis: Does a string of scandals plaguing Singapore's government show that the system of oversight is working, or that such issues are inevitable without independent checks and balances?

title.children: 'Whiter than white': Why Singapore's recent spate of scandals have rocked the country

image.altText: Martin, Selena and Steve look at something beyond the camera with a shocked expression as they stand on a stage.

items.synopsis: With the most Oscar nominations in history, Meryl Streep hardly needs an introduction. But if you're yet to watch Only Murders in the Building, here's everything you need to know ahead of season three.

title.children: Meryl Streep has joined Only Murders in the Building. Here's your guide to the 'cosy crime' series

image.altText: Penny Wong, wearing a floral wreath in her hair, kneels next to Kiribati children holding Australian flags

items.synopsis: Australia will require both climate and gender objectives in much of its foreign aid spending, under a new framework aimed at strengthening Australia's influence in the Indo-Pacific.

title.children: China, climate and gender equality: Australia's new foreign aid policy aimed at building influence in Pacific

image.altText: NSW RFS battle a blaze at Wentworth Falls in the Blue Mountains, August 3, 2015.

items.synopsis: The first recommendation suggested by counsel assisting the coronial inquiry is the creation of national standards for firefighting truck cabins, with "three tragic incidents" highlighting the need to reassess safety.

title.children: Firefighting truck standards lead closing submissions at NSW Bushfires Coronial Inquiry

image.altText: A man in a camouflage jacket with his arms crossed is spoken to in a police interview room

items.synopsis: Family and friends of the slain teen clapped and sighed with relief in court in Dubbo this morning when Craig Rumsby, 56, was jailed for at least 24 years.

title.children: For 24 years this man got away with murder. Today Michelle Bright's family finally saw justice

image.altText: nurses and midwives at a trike for better pay and conditions

items.synopsis: The vote by the NSW Nurses and Midwives' Association staves off industrial action, but the union says its members recognise 4 per cent isn't enough and vow to continue their fight for better pay.

title.children: NSW nurses accept government's 4pc pay rise in narrow vote 'driven by cost of living'

image.altText: An illustration of a boy staring out a window from behind.

items.synopsis: Almost 33 per cent of Australians feel disconnected socially, and one in six feels severely lonely, according to a landmark study. But there are ways to feel less alone.

title.children: 'They feel really ashamed': Millions of Australians are lonely, but many find it hard to admit
